title.narrative: Reviving Agricultural TVET in Ghana by integrating Farm Institutions (Fl's) in the wider agricultural education system with public agricultural colleges and universities

description.narrative:
**Objective**
End hunger and children's undernourishment, double smallholder productivity and income, and ensure the sustainability and resilience of food production systems by 2030 (SDG 2)
**Long-term impact**
End hunger and children's undernourishment, double smallholder productivity and income, and ensure the sustainability and resilience of food production systems by 2030 (SDG 2)
**Outcome(s) at project level**
ATVET/HE organizations (In Ghana and in NL) perform better their core tasks, firmly embedded in their environment (in line with Ghanaian/ regional specific labour market needs & aiming at marginalized inclusiveness and gender mainstreaming).
The following proposed outputs will contribute directly to achieving the project outcomes: - The Farm Institutes offer gender sensitive CBET education by certified teachers - The Farm Institutes implement COTVET accredited new and revised demand-driven, and industry led curricula that are gender sensitive - The Farm Institutes possess the organizational and infrastructural capacity to implement the new and revised curricula - Entrepreneurship capacity of the Farm Institutes enhanced (for students and the tutors)

Farm Institutes’ staff and management, Ghanaian students of Farm Institutes, Ghanaian student about to start agro start-ups, practicing (small holder) farmers, Dutch TVET students, (too limited extent) management of Co

This project is developed by a consortium consisting of the 3 public Farm Institutes, Kwadaso Agricultural Colleges, Sunyani Technical University, MSM, InHolland, Q-point, CINOP, Graafschap College and KNUST.
The project aims to contribute to SDG 2: “End hunger and children's undernourishment, double smallholder productivity and income, and ensure the sustainability and resilience of food production systems by 2030” by realizing the following outcome:
ATVET/HE organizations perform better their core tasks, firmly embedded in their environment (in line with Ghanaian/ regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness)
Our aim is to enhance the educational and organizational capacity of the three Farm Institutes. These are currently challenged, as they can’t attract sufficient students. However, the FI’s are very important in strengthening the agricultural potential of the Ghanaian population. And therefore this consortium supports them to rebrand the institutes in order to enhance their image, become more attractive for secondary education graduates as well as professional agriculturalists.
The consortium aims to enhance the sustainability of the partnership through a mix of activities, such as: staff exchange, guest lecturing and joint projects, with special attention of implementing projects that contribute to address the needs of people from marginalized groups and to realise gender equality.

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Successful inception workshop for reviving Ghanaian agricultural TVETs project
Year in review: Reviving agricultural TVET in Ghana
Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: A. TVET/HE organisations perform better their core tasks, firmly embedded in their environment
A.E.5. Number of curricula for degree, non-degree and short courses revised/newly developed

description.narrative: Degree: bachelor's, master's and doctorate Non degree: Certificate and diploma

comment.narrative:
24-11-2020: In June 2020, occupational standards have been developed and are validated by COTVET for the following educational programs: - Livestock and Meat Production - Agribusiness - Mechanization and Irrigation - Tree Crop Production - Arable Crop - Poultry Value Chain.
The DACUM workshops and Validation workshops had to be re-designed in online workshops, which required more time than the originally planned face-to-face workshops. The curriculum development steps were therefore delayed. Now that the occupational standards are validated by COTVET, the final curriculum development phase can start.
Tailor made short courses are under development
For 6 short courses accreditation is in its final stages.

title.narrative: A.O.10. Diversity in management and teaching staff (i.e. balance in junior/senior staff, women/men, minorities)

description.narrative: please enclose stories of change or examples of best practices

actual.value:
- Gender balance improved.
- Junior-senior staff ratio improved.
- Minorities still to be addressed.

title.narrative: A.O.1. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the knowledge institution

description.narrative: please enclose stories of change or examples of best practices

actual.value: The Farm Institutes have been part of the gender strategy development for the Colleges by the NICHE-GHA-270 project. The strategy needs to only be validated and adapted for use by the Farm Institutes

title.narrative: A.R.2. Number of relevant publications (level, gender, inclusion)

comment.narrative: 24-11-2020: -Report on cocoa production (MSM) -Work on academic progression (Dr. Theophilos) -White paper on online learning

title.narrative: A.E.7. Student satisfaction

comment.narrative: 24-11-2020: A baseline survey has been conducted among students. Overall student satisfaction was reasonable (60% would completely recommend studying at one of the farm institutes). Some alumni indicate the financial skills, curriculum, and infrastructure can be improved.

title.narrative: A.E.3. Number of staff that have gained qualitative and relevant knowledge and skills to develop and offer the revised/developed study programmes

comment.narrative:
24-11-2020: Curriculum development has been almost realized. Only during/after implementation, staff training can start. This has been delayed because of Covid-19. Training in Occupational Standards has been realized.
Face-to-face CBET teacher trainings are delayed because of the inability to travel for international CBET experts. Because of the rural location of the farm institutes, we deem it impossible to re-design the CBET training to online training
In the indicator section of the 'outcome at project level' 50 staff are mentioned, of which 25% female

title.narrative: A.O.5. Number of organisations that have developed and implemented a system to regularly survey the satisfaction of students, short courses participants, graduates and/or employers

comment.narrative: 24-11-2020: Delay because of Covid 19

title.narrative: A.O.3. Number of organisations revised/developed institutional mechanism for quality assurance

comment.narrative: 24-11-2020: Delay because of Covid 19

title.narrative: A.O.4. Number of organisations with a revised/developed system to registrate and monitor its alumni

comment.narrative: 24-11-2020: Delay because of Covid 19

title.narrative: A.E.2. Increased participation of students from minorities

comment.narrative: 24-11-2020: Due to planning changes and COVID-19, this is more suitable to be achieved later on in the project. (Planned for year 3)

title.narrative: A.O.12. Number of organisations with policies and procedures to ensure an environment which is conducive for minorities

comment.narrative:
24-11-2020: Even though this sub-output is planned for year 2, in August 2020 a feasibility study has been done by a local expert (Dr. Theophilus Adomako) on academic progression and upward educational mobility for graduates of the farm institutes within the context of the developed Occupational Standards. As students of the farm institutes belong to the most vulnerable groups in Ghana (rural, marginalized), the farm institutes need to become a place of opportunities. The feasibility study is a first step in achieving this goal. This study has been assessed by the HR department of MOFA and was highly appreciated
Effectuation of this study is planned for year 2.

title.narrative: A.O.7. % of women in management of faculty/department

comment.narrative: 24-11-2020: Female vice principal installed at Adidome Farm Institute

title.narrative: A.S.3. Number of students performing an internship or practical work

comment.narrative:
24-11-2020: Internships were being prepared in the first half of the project year 1. However, due to the COVID outbreak it was not possible to actually place the students in the companies.
The curriculum is not yet ready to allow for admission of new students. The existing old curriculum does not make room for industrial attachments
75% of the students who participated in the new/revised curricula

title.narrative: A.S.2. Number of MoUs or other types of collaboration agreements signed (education, private, public, surrounding community)

comment.narrative: 24-11-2020: MOU under development with NEIP (National Entrepreneurship Innovation Program)

title.narrative: A.E.6. Number of students enrolled in revised/newly developed study programmes

comment.narrative: 24-11-2020: Not Applicable yet. The implementation of the six educational programs is not yet finalized.
In the indicator section of the 'outcome at project level' 200 graduates are mentioned

title.narrative: A.O.6. Number of facilities established/strengthened

comment.narrative: 24-11-2020: Online learning and communication facilities improved. Further strengthening required. Online training has been introduced, not previously existing.

title.narrative: A.O.11. Number of organisations with policies and procedures to ensure an environment which is gender sensitive

comment.narrative:
24-11-2020: Staff has participated in the NICHE gender training for strategy development
Formalization of the strategy will be finalized in year 2

title.narrative: A.O.2. Number of organisations revised/developed and implemented a strategic plan

comment.narrative: 24-11-2020: The Farm Institutes have a draft strategic plan in place. Some revision to capture the current ongoing interventions is needed but can only take place after complete revision of curriculum and implementation started.

title.narrative: A.S.4. Number of SMEs supported

comment.narrative:
24-11-2020: The focus for year 1 was more on curriculum development. Also, because the internships have not started yet, the connection with the SME’s is not that strong. For year 2, there are possibilities to support the SME’s in overcoming the challenges due to the COVID outbreak. Financial support for income generating activities at the FI’s will be allocated in Q3 of 2020
In July and early August, a consultant is undertaking scoping of industries that the farm institutes can collaborate with for future internships
